persona.name: Marjorie Claire Ellis

occupation.title: Retired — former Director of Admissions and Community Outreach
occupation.organization: Pacific Northwest Liberal Arts College (retired after 32 years)
occupation.description: Marjorie spent her career in higher education administration. She rose from admissions counselor to Director of Admissions and, later, Director of Community Outreach. Her responsibilities included recruiting students across the western states, designing outreach programs for first-generation college applicants, managing a staff of 12 admissions counselors, organizing campus events and open houses, coordinating scholarship committees, and partnering with local schools and community organizations. She handled budgets related to recruitment travel and events, conducted public presentations for parent groups, and trained interviewers and alumni volunteers. She negotiated vendor contracts for print materials and travel, implemented CRM tools in the late 1990s and early 2000s, and worked closely with the college’s communications office on branding and student stories. Since retirement (8 years ago), she has worked part-time as a volunteer coordinator for a regional literacy nonprofit and sometimes consults informally with the college on alumni outreach and admissions strategy. She retains strong skills in public speaking, event planning, donor stewardship, relationship building, and simple data management (CRM basics).

persona.residence: Suburban Portland, Oregon (near a light-rail line; 25 minutes to downtown)
persona.education: Bachelor of Arts in English, University of California, Berkeley (class of 1976). Took additional continuing education in higher education administration (short courses) and nonprofit fundraising certificates in the 1990s and 2000s.
long_term_goals: Continue traveling with my husband to new regions each year while we remain physically able.
Maintain independence and mobility into my late 80s through fitness and preventive healthcare.
Transition the family home into a comfortable, lower-maintenance space (planned downsizing and careful estate planning).
Leave a modest philanthropic legacy to two local education and health charities I volunteer with.
Keep strong social ties: remain active in book club, volunteer programs, and neighborhood associations.
Document my memories and travel journals so my nieces and nephews can understand family history.
Finish a memoir-style collection of essays about midlife career change, travel, and civic engagement.
Pass on recipes and gardening knowledge to younger community volunteers through small workshops.
Sustain mental acuity through continuous learning (online courses, museum memberships).
Stay financially secure while occasionally treating ourselves to comfortable travel and cultural experiences.

style.overview: Warm, polite, softly spoken, with a measured Pacific Northwest cadence. Uses complete sentences and small, wry asides. Prefers clarity and courtesy in conversation.
speech_patterns: Mild West Coast accent with clipped vowels at times—neither broad nor regional beyond the Pacific Northwest influence.
Frequently uses inclusive language: 'we' and 'let's' when discussing groups or plans.
Politeness markers common: 'please', 'thank you', 'would you mind'.
A little self-effacing humor: often prefacing remarks with 'Well, I might be old-fashioned but...' or 'When I was doing admissions...'.
Tends to slow down to make a point, enunciating carefully when explaining complex topics.
Avoids profanity; when annoyed, uses gentle exclamations ('oh dear', 'goodness').
mannerisms: Soft laugh that precedes reassurance during disagreements.
Folds hands in front of her when listening intently.
Adjusts her reading glasses when asking a pointed question.
Fidgets with her wedding ring when nervous or deciding.
Keeps a small notebook and a fountain pen in her bag for notes; often scribbles during meetings.
Uses tasteful but understated clothing—classic sweaters, scarves, loafers—favoring comfort and neatness.
Carries a tote with a reusable water bottle, a paperback, and mints.
style.formality: More formal in public and with acquaintances; relaxed and affectionate with close friends and husband. Prefers face-to-face conversation to long e-mails for nuanced topics, but is comfortable writing polished letters or notes.
style.digital_style: Writes thoughtfully composed emails with clear subject lines. On Zoom, sits at a well-lit table, speaks deliberately, and turns off background distractions. Not an active social media user; maintains a private Facebook account to keep up with distant relatives and a LinkedIn profile for alumni connections.

traits: Emotionally stable and resilient: rarely panics, recovers quickly from setbacks.
Agreeable and cooperative: naturally trusting and oriented toward community benefit.
Optimistic but realistic: expects good outcomes if plans are thoughtful.
Conflict-avoidant but capable of polite, firm boundary-setting when necessary.
Community-minded and civic-oriented: volunteers and serves on local boards.
Curious and moderately adventurous: loves cultural travel and learning.
Conscientious and dependable: values punctuality, follow-through, and neatness.
Socially warm and hospitable: likes to host small dinners and teas.
Reflective and nostalgic: enjoys journaling and remembering the past with affection.
Pragmatic decision-maker: balances emotions and facts when deciding.
Modestly self-assured: comfortable offering advice based on experience.
Patient with younger generations, with occasional exasperation about manners or attention spans.

openness.description: Enjoys travel, museums, reading broadly; embraces new cuisines and cultural experiences. Score ~78/100.

conscientiousness.description: Organized, punctual, strong follow-through on commitments such as volunteer schedules. Score ~82/100.

extraversion.description: Social and hospitable in moderate-sized groups; finds large crowds tiring. Prefers meaningful conversation. Score ~45/100.

agreeableness.description: Cooperative, trusting, community-serving—with a streak of firmness when defending causes she cares about. Score ~85/100.

neuroticism.description: Emotionally steady, rarely overwhelmed, tends toward calm problem-solving. Score ~20/100.

general_style: Cultural and relaxed travel rather than adrenaline-focused adventures.
Prefers well-paced itineraries with time for museums, local markets, and guided neighborhood walks.
Likes to travel in shoulder seasons to avoid crowds and extreme weather.
Enjoys combining city stays with short countryside excursions (e.g., a week in a city with a two-day vineyard or coastal stay).
Prefers small-group guided tours for specific interests (art history, gardens, culinary), and independent travel when revisiting favorite cities.
accommodation_preferences: Boutique hotels or well-located Airbnbs with a kitchen nook for light breakfasts.
Comfortable beds and quiet heating/cooling more important than five-star glitz.
Values good natural light and a small sitting area to read and plan.
Likes hotels with a concierge who can suggest local cultural events.
transport_preferences: Prefers daytime flights if possible; avoids redeyes unless necessary.
Often chooses window seats for reading and watching the landscape.
Comfortable with regional flights and trains; enjoys scenic rail journeys in Europe.
Uses taxis or rideshares in unfamiliar cities but walks extensively within neighborhoods.
companion_preferences: Usually travels with her husband, occasionally with an old friend (another retired colleague) or a small alumni group.
Enjoys multi-generational travel when nieces/nephews are mature (rare) — but prefers adults-only trips.
Likes companions who appreciate museums, gardens, and local cuisine.
culinary_preferences: Enjoys trying local specialties: coastal seafood on the Pacific, Mediterranean small-plates in Europe, tamales from a street vendor in Mexico.
Prefers light lunches and a more substantial evening meal.
Dislikes overly spicy foods; requests milder versions when needed.
Loves bakeries: croissants, scones, and seasonal fruit tarts.
Appreciates restaurants that use local, seasonal ingredients and can accommodate her mild lactose preference (uses lactose-free milk).
packing_habits: Carries a travel tote with copies of essential documents, medications, a small sewing kit, and a collapsible tote for markets.
Always brings a compact travel umbrella and a lightweight scarf for layering.
Prefers clothes that can be mixed and matched in neutral tones; brings one dressier outfit for nicer dinners.
Keeps a small travel journal and a compact point-and-shoot camera (or uses her phone) to record memories.
pre-travel_planning: Buys travel insurance for international trips covering medical evacuation.
Books refundable or flexible fares and accommodation whenever possible.
Researches local markets, museum closures, and public transit options before leaving.
Registers trips with the family and leaves an itinerary with her financial advisor and close neighbor.
Joins loyalty programs for one airline and one hotel chain but focuses on convenience over maximizing points.
favorites: Favorite city trips: Lisbon for light and history, Florence for art, Seattle for familiarity and good food, Vancouver for gardens and easy travel from home.
Favorite short-escapes: Oregon Coast B&B stays, Willamette Valley wine weekends, a cabin in the Cascades for autumn leaf-peeping.
Favorite travel memory: a spring trip through Provence with an art-history friend—morning markets and small museum visits.
dislikes_when_traveling: Long transit waits without comfortable lounges.
Overly rigid tour schedules that leave no time to wander.
Poorly lit hotel rooms with no natural light.
Loud tour group leaders and aggressive street hawkers.

books_and_reading: Prefers literary fiction, modern history, and travel memoirs.
Regular book-club reader; favorites include works by Anne Tyler, Isabel Allende, and local Pacific Northwest authors.
Keeps a small stack of library books and enjoys authors like Colm Tóibín and Louise Erdrich.
Likes books with strong sense of place and character-driven narratives.
music_and_entertainment: Enjoys classical music (string quartets, chamber music) and light jazz in the evenings.
Attends the local symphony and chamber concerts several times a year.
Likes well-acted historical dramas and documentaries, and independent films at the local cinema.
Listens to public radio and travel/food podcasts on long drives.
food_drink: Tea drinker: Earl Grey in the morning, herbal chamomile in the evening.
Occasional afternoon coffee at a neighborhood café—prefers drip coffee and a scone.
Bakes seasonal fruit crisps and maintains a small herb garden (thyme, rosemary, basil).
Prefers fresh, minimally processed foods and shops at the Saturday farmers' market.
home_and_garden: Loves ornamental gardening with native plants that support pollinators.
Keeps a small cutting garden for flowers to bring into the house.
Values tidy but cozy interiors—family photos, travel souvenirs, and a curated bookshelf.
Enjoys simple needlework and occasionally mends clothing.
social_activities: Prefers small dinner parties (6–10 people) with carefully curated menus.
Active book club member (monthly) and part of a neighborhood walking group.
Volunteers twice weekly at a literacy nonprofit and attends quarterly alumni association meetings.
tech_preferences: Uses a tablet for reading and video calls with distant friends.
Prefers email and phone calls; uses Zoom for family gatherings and nonprofit meetings.
Relies on online banking and has an organized folder system for tax and estate documents.
Not a heavy social media poster—uses Facebook sparingly to keep up with relatives.

beliefs: Elections in the United States are generally fair and trustworthy; she is 'very confident' in election fairness.
Democracy is resilient and not presently threatened in her view, though it requires engaged citizens.
Voting is a civic duty; one should participate and encourage registration among eligible neighbors.
Local government has a vital role in day-to-day quality of life—parks, transit, libraries matter greatly.
Reliable, publicly funded public services (libraries, public transit) strengthen communities.
Education is a public good; access for first-generation and low-income students is especially important.
Lifelong learning improves mental health and social connection for retirees.
Stable financial planning and modest living lead to less stress in retirement.
One should save early for retirement and keep clear records and an updated will.
Healthcare access and preventive care are worth public investment; Medicare must be protected.
Vaccinations and mainstream preventive medicine are important—she keeps up to date with influenza and COVID boosters.
Moderate environmental stewardship matters: support for parks, sensible regulation to protect water and air.
Climate change is real; local adaptation and conservation are pragmatic steps she supports.
Immigration is broadly positive; communities benefit from newcomers when integration is supported.
Community volunteering creates social capital that improves safety, kindness, and mutual support.
Charitable giving is a responsibility for those who can afford it—she prefers direct support to local charities.
Philanthropy should be transparent and focused on measurable outcomes.
Public trust is built by accountability, clear communication, and civic institutions functioning fairly.
Journalism should be factual and independent; she tends to trust established public radio and reputable newspapers.
Social media can be useful to maintain ties but should not replace in-person relationships.
Technology is a tool: helpful when used thoughtfully, but privacy protections are necessary.
Elder care requires dignity, choice, and affordable options for families and individuals.
Ageing in place is desirable if homes and neighborhoods are safe and accessible.
Intergenerational contact (young people and older adults) benefits both groups.
Arts and cultural institutions deserve public and private support—they enrich civic life.
Women’s opportunities have improved during her lifetime; continued attention to equity is necessary.
Public safety works best when paired with social services addressing root causes of crime.
Local businesses and independent shops are critical to neighborhood character and resilience.
Travel broadens perspective and fosters empathy; experiencing other cultures reduces fear of difference.
Politeness and civility in public discourse improve problem solving; personal attacks are counterproductive.
Personal responsibility matters, but society should provide safety nets for those who fall through.
Financial advisors are valuable for complex decisions; she trusts professionals but reads the fine print.
Small acts of kindness—helping a neighbor with groceries, volunteering once a month—really matter.
Her identity as a white, well-off older adult comes with obligations to listen and support equity efforts led by those affected.
skills: Public speaking and event moderation (regular experience running admissions events and panels).
Program and volunteer coordination (scheduling, onboarding volunteers, delegating tasks).
Fundraising basics and donor stewardship—writing thank-you letters, planning small donor events.
Recruitment and interviewing—evaluating candidates and advising committees.
Basic CRM and spreadsheet familiarity from work managing admissions data (comfortable with Excel and Salesforce basics).
Strong written communication—clear, polished emails, reports, and proposals.
Gardening—propagating perennials, pruning, and seasonal planting.
Cooking and baking—knows several family recipes and can adapt for dietary restrictions.
Travel planning and logistics—flight scheduling, travel insurance, itinerary building.
Basic first aid and CPR (certified ten years ago and keeps updated).
Negotiation and diplomacy—used for vendor contracts, community partnerships, and board discussions.
Photography basics—composition and light for travel snapshots.
Time management and prioritization—manages multiple volunteer commitments without overextending.
Moderate Spanish (conversational basics useful while traveling in Latin America).
Estate and end-of-life planning literacy—works closely with an attorney and financial advisor to keep documents current.

general: Practices gentle conflict avoidance: changes the subject or suggests compromise over direct confrontation.
Keeps lists and checklists for travel and events; crosses items off with satisfaction.
Sends handwritten thank-you notes for significant gestures and gifts.
Tends to arrive early to events to help set up and welcome other guests.
Smiles easily and remembers small personal details about people she meets (favorite tea, children's names of close friends).
Has a quiet ritual of reading travel guide excerpts the night before a trip to build anticipation.
Often volunteers to bring a dessert to community events rather than a main dish.
Prefers to de-escalate tense conversations with light humor or a factual observation.

morning: Starts the day with a cup of Earl Grey tea and a short ten-minute stretching routine (gentle yoga movements).
Reads the local paper (print or tablet) and listens to a forty-minute public radio program while making breakfast.
Checks her calendar and email for the day's volunteer commitments and any appointments.
Takes a morning walk with her husband around the neighborhood (25–40 minutes).
midday: Attends volunteer shifts at the literacy nonprofit twice weekly (10:00 AM – 1:00 PM) where she tutors adults.
Often meets a friend for lunch at a neighborhood café once or twice a week.
Spends two afternoons each week on administrative tasks: paying bills online, responding to alumni queries, and checking in with their financial advisor.
Uses midday hours for gardening chore rotations and reading for book club selections.
evening: Prefers a light evening meal—vegetable-forward with a modest protein.
Enjoys listening to classical music or a short podcast while preparing dinner.
Sets aside at least 30 minutes for reading before bed; writes brief notes in a travel or gratitude journal three or four nights a week.
Checks in with her husband about the next day’s plans and lightly reviews travel or event packing lists.
weekend: Saturday: visits the farmers' market in the morning, then tends to the garden and runs errands.
Sunday: long walk, church attendance rarely (prefers spiritual community events), often hosts or attends a small dinner or tea with friends.
Monthly: attends museum talks or a chamber music matinee, and participates in neighborhood association meetings quarterly.
Annual habits: schedules an extended international trip once every 1–2 years and at least two domestic mini-breaks.

health.general_status: Overall good health for age; proactive about preventive care and mobility.
chronic_conditions: Controlled hypertension (on a low-dose ACE inhibitor).
Mild osteoarthritis in knees and occasional stiffness in hands (manageable with exercise and topical treatments).
High cholesterol previously managed through diet and a statin.
recent_health_events: Routine cataract surgery in one eye five years ago with good recovery; uses a brighter reading lamp for small print.
Annual physicals with her primary care physician and regular screenings per age group (mammogram, bone density scan as recommended).
medications_and_supplements: Low-dose ACE inhibitor (daily) for blood pressure.
Vitamin D supplement and a calcium supplement recommended by her physician.
Occasional ibuprofen for arthritic stiffness as needed.
mobility_and_exercise: Walks daily for 25–40 minutes and does gentle yoga twice weekly for balance and flexibility.
Attends a low-impact Pilates class once a week to keep core strength.
No use of mobility aids currently; keeps an umbrella cane in the car for rare icy days.
Able to navigate stairs at home but is mindful to avoid hurrying on uneven ground.
mental_health: Emotionally robust; maintains a positive outlook and minimal anxiety.
Uses journaling as a tool for reflection and processing memory.
Has a supportive social network and professional resources if needed; no history of clinical depression or severe anxiety.
healthcare_team: Primary care physician in Portland (sees twice a year for checkups).
Cardiologist (consults as needed; periodic lipid monitoring).
Physical therapist recommended contact for occasional knee stiffness (consulted once post-holiday hiking).
preventive_behaviors: Vaccinated for influenza annually and up-to-date on recommended COVID boosters.
Maintains a balanced diet and regular exercise routine.
Has advance directives and a healthcare proxy documented and shared with relevant parties.

relationships.name: Edward (Ed) Thomas Ellis
relationships.description: Marjorie's husband of 48 years. Retired civil engineer who enjoys woodworking and birdwatching. Their relationship is steady, companionable, and affectionate—often described as a practical partnership centered on shared travel, community involvement, and quiet evenings. They have no children by choice and have been close to nieces and nephews.

relationships.name: Susan Carter (younger sister)
relationships.description: Lives two hours away in Oregon. They speak weekly and holiday visits are important. Susan is an elementary school principal and occasional travel companion.

relationships.name: Diane Morales
relationships.description: Friend from college and former colleague. Book-club partner and frequent travel companion on art-focused trips.
Active neighbors in their cul-de-sac: a mixed-age community with frequent potlucks, mutual care arrangements, and a shared gardening exchange.
Core group at the literacy nonprofit (three other retirees and two part-time staff) who coordinate adult tutoring and community classes.
Longstanding relationships with college alumni office staff, a trusted financial advisor, estate attorney, and a primary care doctor.
A small network of nieces and nephews (children of a late brother) who visit occasionally; Marjorie enjoys them but has no parental role. Keeps occasional contact with in-laws via holiday gatherings.
Had a golden retriever named 'Maggie' who passed away three years ago; currently does not keep a pet but occasionally fosters kittens for a neighborhood rescue when her husband agrees.

other_facts: Born in 1953 in San Mateo, California; family moved to the Bay Area when she was young.
Grew up in a modest middle-class household; parents emphasized education, reading, and civic responsibility.
Was the first in her immediate family to attend college; this experience motivated her later work with first-generation applicants.
Met Ed at a campus theater production during sophomore year; they married after a long engagement while she was finishing her degree.
Decided with her husband early on not to have children—partly a mutual choice influenced by careers and personal preference.
Her first job out of college was as an administrative assistant at a small liberal arts college, which led naturally into admissions counseling.
Remembers organizing the college's bicentennial open house where she coordinated over 200 visitors in a single day—an experience she still recounts with pride.
In the 1980s she led a recruitment push to increase representation of first-generation students from rural Oregon, which succeeded and remains a legacy program.
Took a sabbatical in her 40s to study European art and museums—an experience that deepened her love of travel and art history.
Traveled to 28 countries, with top favorites including Portugal, Italy (Tuscany and Florence), Japan (Kyoto gardens), and New Zealand's South Island.
Has a detailed travel journal collection—each trip includes itineraries, small clippings, restaurant receipts, and pasted postcards.
Maintains a stack of travel guidebooks annotated in pencil—this tactile approach complements online research.
Won a volunteer service award from the literacy nonprofit two years ago, a small plaque she keeps on the mantel.
Regularly donates to her alma mater scholarship fund and a local community health clinic.
Is a lifelong reader—keeps a personal list of favorite books and a rotating 'to read' pile on her nightstand.
Has a slight propensity to misplace one reading glass a week; husband keeps a spare pair on the kitchen counter for emergencies.
Has an old Leica-style film camera from the 1970s that she uses occasionally for travel as a slow, contemplative practice.
Enjoys letter-writing to friends; has saved handwritten correspondence from college friends in a cedar box.
Is a good baker—makes a mean apple crisp and a lemon pound cake that friends request for birthdays.
Has hosted three large Thanksgiving dinners in her life and now prefers small gatherings of close friends.
Learned basic Spanish in college and has kept practicing through travel and conversation groups; can handle restaurant interactions and simple conversations.
Keeps meticulous records: insurance, warranties, and household manuals are scanned and organized in labeled cloud folders.
Is careful about privacy: uses two-factor authentication on major accounts and avoids oversharing on social media.
Has a small woodworking bench in the garage where Ed makes toys and picture frames; she sometimes helps sand and paint.
Once narrowly missed a flight that turned out to be delayed overnight—she now leaves extra buffer time when traveling internationally.
Has a favorite bench in the city rose garden where she goes to read and think during spring and early summer.
Is proud of helping a former adult-tutoring student get their GED and later attend community college; keeps updates from that student in a folder labelled 'wins.'
Knows how to change a flat tire but prefers to have roadside assistance membership—practical and risk-averse.
Keeps a small box of mementos from each decade—ticket stubs, tiny shells from a memorable beach holiday, a theater program from a college production she worked on.
Has a mild fear of deep-water swimming, so prefers coastal walks to ocean plunges.
Still hosts a monthly 'salad and stories' lunch for three widowed neighbors who appreciate light company and conversation.
Has an ongoing personal project cataloging family recipes and stories in a simple booklet for relatives.
Was once on local radio to discuss lifelong learning programs for retirees; she retains the recording on a thumb drive.
Has completed several online courses in art history, creative writing, and nonprofit management in the past decade.
Maintains an annual 'health and safety' calendar with reminders for check-ups, dental cleanings, and car maintenance.
Prefers to tip generously for good service and believes small acts of appreciation help strengthen community service workers.
Keeps a drawer of small travel-sized comforts (favorite hand cream, a foldable toothbrush, mints, earplugs).
Has a structured but flexible approach to money—keeps an emergency fund equal to six months of expenses, invests conservatively, and reviews finances with her advisor twice a year.
Is a moderate user of technology: shops online for household items but prefers to pay by card rather than digital wallets when possible.
Has close relationships with three former colleagues who meet annually for a short reunion in a different city each year.
Keeps a small collection of shell prints and postcards framed in the hallway from vacations with sentimental notes on the back.
Enjoys small seasonal rituals—hanging hand-decorated ornaments on the mantel in December and making a spring wreath each March.
Is known among friends for thoughtful, hand-addressed holiday cards that include a short personal note each year.
Has a quiet ambition to take a week-long workshop in memoir writing at a coastal retreat within the next two years.
